drug.name: Aminolevulinic acid
drug.description: A compound produced from succinyl-CoA and glycine as an intermediate in heme synthesis. It is used as a photochemotherapy for actinic keratosis. [PubChem]

article.citation: Stummer W, Pichlmeier U, Meinel T, Wiestler OD, Zanella F, Reulen HJ: Fluorescence-guided surgery with 5-aminolevulinic acid for resection of malignant glioma: a randomised controlled multicentre phase III trial. Lancet Oncol. 2006 May;7(5):392-401.

Kennedy JC, Marcus SL, Pottier RH: Photodynamic therapy (PDT) and photodiagnosis (PD) using endogenous photosensitization induced by 5-aminolevulinic acid (ALA): mechanisms and clinical results. J Clin Laser Med Surg. 1996 Oct;14(5):289-304.

drug.synthesis-reference: Takashi Ebata, Hiroshi Kawakami, Katsuya Matsumoto, Koshi Koseki, Hajime Matsushita, "Method of preparing an acid additional salt of delta-aminolevulinic acid." U.S. Patent US5284973, issued July, 1974.
drug.indication: Aminolevulinic acid plus blue light illumination using a blue light photodynamic therapy illuminator is indicated for the treatment of minimally to moderately thick actinic keratoses of the face or scalp.
drug.pharmacodynamics: The metabolism of aminolevulinic acid (ALA) is the first step in the biochemical pathway resulting in heme synthesis. Aminolevulinic acid is not a photosensitizer, but rather a metabolic precursor of protoporphyrin IX (PpIX), which is a photosensitizer. The synthesis of ALA is normally tightly controlled by feedback inhibition of the enzyme, ALA synthetase, presumably by intracellular heme levels. ALA, when provided to the cell, bypasses this control point and results in the accumulation of PpIX, which is converted into heme by ferrochelatase through the addition of iron to the PpIX nucleus.
drug.mechanism-of-action: According to the presumed mechanism of action, photosensitization following application of aminolevulinic acid (ALA) topical solution occurs through the metabolic conversion of ALA to protoporphyrin IX (PpIX), which accumulates in the skin to which aminolevulinic acid has been applied. When exposed to light of appropriate wavelength and energy, the accumulated PpIX produces a photodynamic reaction, a cytotoxic process dependent upon the simultaneous presence of light and oxygen. The absorption of light results in an excited state of the porphyrin molecule, and subsequent spin transfer from PpIX to molecular oxygen generates singlet oxygen, which can further react to form superoxide and hydroxyl radicals. Photosensitization of actinic (solar) keratosis lesions using aminolevulinic acid, plus illumination with the BLU-UTM Blue Light Photodynamic Therapy Illuminator (BLU-U), is the basis for aminolevulinic acid photodynamic therapy (PDT).
drug.toxicity: Solution overdose have not been reported.
drug.metabolism: Following topical administration, synthesis into protoporphyrin IX takes place in situ in the skin.
drug.half-life: Mean half-life is 0.70 ± 0.18 h after the oral dose and 0.83 ± 0.05 h after the intravenous dose.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as delta amino acids and derivatives. These are compounds containing a carboxylic acid group and an amino group at the C5 carbon atom.

category.category: Misc. Skin and Mucous Membrane Agents

drug-interaction.name: Darbepoetin alfa
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of Thrombosis can be increased when Darbepoetin alfa is combined with Aminolevulinic acid.

drug-interaction.name: Erythropoietin
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of Thrombosis can be increased when Erythropoietin is combined with Aminolevulinic acid.

drug-interaction.name: Peginesatide
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of Thrombosis can be increased when Peginesatide is combined with Aminolevulinic acid.

drug-interaction.name: Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of Thrombosis can be increased when Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta is combined with Aminolevulinic acid.

drug-interaction.name: Porfimer sodium
drug-interaction.description: Aminolevulinic acid may increase the photosensitizing activities of Porfimer sodium.

drug-interaction.name: Verteporfin
drug-interaction.description: Aminolevulinic acid may increase the photosensitizing activities of Verteporfin.

pathway.name: Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria (CEP) or Gunther Disease

polypeptide.name: Delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase
polypeptide.specific-function: Catalyzes an early step in the biosynthesis of tetrapyrroles. Binds two molecules of 5-aminolevulinate per subunit, each at a distinct site, and catalyzes their condensation to form porphobilinogen.

article.citation: Terada T, Sawada K, Irie M, Saito H, Hashimoto Y, Inui K: Structural requirements for determining the substrate affinity of peptide transporters PEPT1 and PEPT2. Pflugers Arch. 2000 Sep;440(5):679-84.

polypeptide.name: Solute carrier family 15 member 1
polypeptide.general-function: Proton-dependent oligopeptide secondary active transmembrane transporter activity
polypeptide.specific-function: Proton-coupled intake of oligopeptides of 2 to 4 amino acids with a preference for dipeptides. May constitute a major route for the absorption of protein digestion end-products.

go-classifier.description: proton-dependent oligopeptide secondary active transmembrane transporter activity

polypeptide.name: Solute carrier family 15 member 2
polypeptide.specific-function: Proton-coupled intake of oligopeptides of 2 to 4 amino acids with a preference for dipeptides.
